title: So matches are usually 25 minutes now and the surrender vote's still at 20 minutes

I feel like either I'm misinterpreting your reply or you're talking about the wrong thing.
The issue that Jorencice is talking about is people forgetting to report players that pissed them off.
The issue that you're seemlingly talking about is reporting a lot of people and devaluing your reports.

It's true that if you report falsely then your reports will be devalued, and if you report a lot of people falsely then your reports will be devalued a lot, but if all of your reports are legitimate, you don't have anything to fear. Your reports will be counted normally.

I think the fear is how Riot determines a legitimate report. I'd assume it would be legitimate if they end up being punished. A lot of times players aren't punished, they exhibit toxic behaviors and then don't after that, or they are punished but it takes upwards of several months. So since they don't say exactly how this works, albeit for good reason, there's sort of a fear that your reports don't do anything despite not abusing it, especially when a player you report isn't punished. It can make you feel like your reports have been devalued. So in that sense it's more reassuring to have others report as well, just in case your reports are wrongly devalued.

I understand where the fear is coming from, but people need to realize that Riot doesn't normally punish offenders after just one offense, and that they're unlikely to see the Instant Feedback System confirmation messages saying that their reports got the offenders punished*.
I get that it's reassuring to have others report as well, but if it's a wrong report anyways, then all of those reports are getting devalued, which doesn't help anyone. People should just be confident in their own reports.

You may have felt that they needed to be punished, but the thing is, not everyone who is toxic in one game needs to be punished right away. Sometimes it's just a bad day. Since you only play with the player in one game, you can't really tell if this is a person who deserves to be punished or not. Riot's Instant Feedback System on the other hand can tell if a person is really toxic or if he or she just had a bad day.
It's frustrating that everyone who is mean in-game isn't punished instantly (I really dislike mean people), but there's also the issue of players who think the system is draconian enough already and needs to be toned down. I definitely don't think it should be toned down, but we need to strike a balance between being too harsh and not being harsh enough.

I understand what you're saying, and can agree, to an extent.

That being said, ive had my fair share of bad days where i was extremely rude to other people, and at one point, caught myself a 2-week ban.

Ive seen games make insane comebacks so i have to disagree on this one. Some comps are early game but shit late game. Say Le Blanc, Zed, Ekko jg, and adc and support vs. Malphite, Ahri, Vi jg. Even if they lose early, they can win late game.

It may be possible to make a comeback, but its going to be extremely unpleasant to deal with something like a fed Leblanc for 30 minutes as you play farming simulator with minion waves under tower just to play the game.

Not only is it highly unpleasant, but every patch it seems more and more unlikely and more importantly than all that, _demoralizing._ Nothing quite like a really bad stomp to make me wanna leave League alone, and I hate doing that. I like the damn game.

The higher elo the game, the less chance the team with the lead will end up choking and throwing the game.

P.S. While I agree zed falls off pretty hard, ekko and le blanc keep scaling. Ekko's 3 stack passive and ridiculous ap scalings would melt the enemy tanks and le blanc would pop the squishies. That's also not factoring in that each of those champions have dash/movement abilities and can avoid malph ults and vi cc.
